stories.text:
I always considered myself to be a "good" programmer. Been at it on and off for 15 years now.

That idealization lasted until I decided to tackle a massive project on my own recently, and I'm feeling increasingly unconfident about my abilities.

The more example code I look at implementing, the more I realize just how spaghetti-like what-I-call-programming really is.

I am embarrassed to admit that I don't have the slightest idea what "object oriented" even means.

I have cracked open "Clean Code" recently and have made it half way through "The Pragmatic Programmer" a few years ago ... but can't even find that book anymore :S

Are those even good suggestions for someone like me?

How would you suggest to somebody who already thinks they're a good programmer to go about actually becoming a good programmer?

A bit about me...

- comfortable w/HTML+CSS 20 years go with a SAMS 24 hour book

- comfortable w/PHP 15 years ago with a PHP for Dummies book

- comfortable w/Javascript 15 years ago with the web

- comfortable w/Python 5 years ago through the web

- comfortable w/Node 2 years ago through the web
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Learn to Code Better?

stories.text:
Is depression good of bad for business?

There are many reasons why it's good, escapism for one: who doesn't want to reward themselves after a crappy day by buying something they don't need, with money they don't have, to impress people they don't like? So that can facebook it or tweet it or IG it. Vacations, cars, clothes, fancy restaurants.....

On the other hand, a lot of entrepreneurs wannabes can't get past the risk of not having a steady income, or being ridiculed by family, friends, and peers (depression's cousin anxiety would do that), and all those insecurities and sense of doom is not good to start something, to give light to the multitude of ideas in someone's creative head.

So, is depression good or bad for the economy?
stories.title: Is depression good of bad for the economy?
